components.name: Footer for the application's navigation and copyright information
components.description: A responsive footer component for the application, designed to provide consistent navigation and essential information across all pages. It includes quick links to key sections like 'Getting Started', 'Glossary', 'Component Debugging', and 'Search'. Additionally, it features a dedicated section for 'Teacher Resources' with links to 'PBL Methodology', 'Backward Design', and the 'Teacher Dashboard'. The footer also displays copyright information and a support section with contact guidance. It uses Next.js `Link` components for navigation and Tailwind CSS for styling, ensuring a consistent look and feel.

A comprehensive and responsive header component serving as the primary navigation for the application. It features distinct navigation paths for both students and teachers, including dynamic links to all 8 educational units with brief descriptions, as well as static links to the 'Home', 'Preface', 'Capstone', 'Glossary', and 'Search' pages. The component adapts to different screen sizes, providing a full desktop navigation menu and a collapsible mobile menu (Sheet) for smaller devices. It also integrates a search bar for textbook content. This header ensures easy access to all major sections of the application for both student learning and teacher resource management, supporting the project-based learning curriculum structure.
components.name: Header for the application's main navigation and search functionality
NavigationSidebar for the main application navigation
components.description: A comprehensive sidebar navigation component for the application. It organizes links into three main categories: 'Getting Started' (Home, Preface), 'Semester 1: Mini-Projects' (all 8 educational units), and 'Additional Resources' (Capstone, Glossary, Search). Each unit entry provides a title, a brief description, estimated duration, and a color-coded difficulty level (Beginner, Intermediate, Advanced, Expert). The sidebar utilizes `lucide-react` for icons and custom `Sidebar` UI components to create a structured and easily navigable interface. It is designed to help both students and teachers efficiently access course content and supplementary materials.

components.name: UnitSidebar for unit navigation and progress tracking
components.description: A sticky sidebar component designed for unit-specific navigation and progress tracking within the educational application. It prominently displays the current unit's number, title, and overall completion percentage. The sidebar lists all lessons within the unit, showing each lesson's sequence, title, estimated duration, and individual progress percentage. The current lesson is visually highlighted, and completed lessons are marked with a check icon. Students can click on any lesson to navigate directly to it. The component also provides a quick action button to access the unit's main overview page. It integrates with the `LessonProgressContext` to calculate and display real-time progress for both individual lessons and the entire unit, enhancing the student's awareness of their learning journey. Built using `Card`, `Separator`, `Button`, `Badge`, and `Progress` UI components, and `next/link` for efficient navigation.

A versatile component designed to display and validate individual journal entries, crucial for understanding double-entry bookkeeping. It presents transaction details including entry number, date, and description. Key features include: automatic validation to ensure debits equal credits, with visual feedback (balanced/unbalanced status); optional display of account types (Assets, Liabilities, Equity, Revenue, Expense) with color-coded badges; and an interactive toggle to reveal detailed educational insights. When expanded, it shows the impact on the accounting equation (Assets = Liabilities + Equity) with a breakdown of affected accounts, a transaction analysis summary (number of accounts affected, total value, types of accounts involved), and a clear explanation of double-entry bookkeeping rules. This component is highly configurable, allowing control over the visibility of validation, explanations, and account types, and can be made interactive for student exploration or static for display purposes. It supports the educational objective of reinforcing fundamental accounting principles and transaction analysis.
components.name: JournalEntry for visualizing and validating accounting transactions
TAccountDetailed for visualizing detailed account transactions and balances
components.description: A highly configurable and interactive T-account component designed for detailed visualization of financial transactions. It displays debits and credits for a specific account, including an optional beginning balance. Key features include: dynamic calculation and display of total debits, total credits, and the ending balance; visual indication of the account's normal balance side (debit or credit); and an interactive toggle to show/hide additional details such as transaction categories, journal entry references, and a running balance for each transaction. It also provides an option to display the underlying balance calculation formulas, reinforcing accounting principles. The component highlights abnormal balances with a warning. It supports various account types (asset, liability, equity, revenue, expense) with distinct color coding. This component is ideal for students to analyze the impact of individual transactions on account balances and to understand the mechanics of the double-entry accounting system.

components.name: TAccountSimple for visualizing basic account transactions
components.description: A simplified T-account component designed for a clear and concise overview of an accounting account's activity. It visualizes debits and credits, calculates total debits, total credits, and the ending balance. The component indicates the account's normal balance side (debit or credit) and can optionally display the underlying balance calculation formula. It supports various account types (asset, liability, equity, revenue, expense) with distinct color coding. This component is ideal for demonstrating the basic mechanics of T-accounts and the impact of transactions on account balances without the detailed transaction information found in `TAccountDetailed`.

components.name: TrialBalance for displaying and validating accounting trial balances
components.description: A dynamic and interactive component for displaying a trial balance, a fundamental accounting report. It presents a list of accounts with their debit or credit balances for a specified company and period. Key features include: automatic validation to ensure total debits equal total credits, with clear visual indicators of balance status; options to show/hide account numbers and account types; and the ability to toggle between a flat list view and a grouped view (by account type: Assets, Liabilities, Equity, Revenue, Expenses) for better organization and analysis. When detailed view is enabled, it provides a summary of total accounts, total activity, and a breakdown of balances by account type. The component also includes an educational section explaining the purpose and importance of a trial balance in the accounting cycle. It is designed to be interactive, allowing students to explore different views and understand the structure and validation of a trial balance.

An interactive financial simulation game designed to teach students personal finance management, budgeting skills, and the impact of spending decisions on financial health. Students manage a monthly budget with a fixed income ($5,000) and adjust both required (rent, utilities, groceries, transportation) and optional (entertainment, dining, shopping) expenses. The component provides real-time budget calculations, visual feedback on budget status (over/under), and allows students to advance through months. As months progress, savings accumulate, an emergency fund grows (10% of surplus), and a financial health score (0-100%) updates based on savings rate and spending habits. The game emphasizes understanding fixed vs. variable expenses, the importance of emergency funds, and long-term financial planning. It includes a detailed 'How to Play' section explaining objectives, gameplay, expense categories, financial health scoring, key learning goals, and success tips. The component is self-contained and requires no props.
components.name: BudgetBalancer for personal finance and budgeting simulation
CashFlowChallenge for business liquidity management simulation
components.description: An interactive business simulation game where students manage cash flow to ensure business solvency over 30 days. Starting with $25,000, students must balance incoming customer payments with outgoing expenses (supplier payments, payroll, rent). The game features a real-time cash position monitor, day counter, and a cash health status (Healthy, Good, Tight, Critical, Bankrupt). Students can employ strategic actions to manage liquidity: requesting early payments (with a fee), negotiating payment terms (with a penalty), obtaining a line of credit (with setup fees and daily interest), and delaying non-critical expenses (with penalties). The objective is to survive 30 days with a positive cash balance, learning the critical difference between cash flow and profitability, the importance of payment timing, and strategic options for managing cash shortfalls. The component includes a comprehensive 'How to Play' guide detailing objectives, win/loss conditions, cash health statuses, strategic actions, key payment timelines, and pro tips for success. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: InventoryManager for retail inventory and demand forecasting simulation
components.description: An interactive business simulation game designed to teach students retail inventory management, demand forecasting, and profit optimization over a 30-day period. Students manage a retail electronics store with three product categories (Laptops, Phones, Tablets), each with distinct costs, prices, and demand characteristics. The game dashboard displays current cash, day count, profit/loss, and inventory levels. Students make purchasing decisions, balancing cash flow with inventory needs and considering daily storage costs. The simulation includes dynamic market conditions, with random market events like demand spikes/drops, price changes, and storage discounts, to which students must react. The objective is to maximize profit by balancing inventory levels with demand, minimizing storage costs, and avoiding stockouts. Key learning outcomes include understanding inventory turnover, carrying costs, demand forecasting, purchasing planning, cash flow management in retail, risk management through product mix, and strategic decision-making under uncertainty. The component is fully self-contained and requires no props.

An interactive business simulation game, 'Lemonade Stand Tycoon', designed to teach students fundamental business concepts through hands-on experience. Students manage a virtual lemonade stand, learning about profit and loss, pricing strategies, inventory management, customer satisfaction, and the impact of external factors like weather. The game features a dashboard displaying current cash, day count, total revenue, and profit/loss. Students interact by purchasing supplies (lemons, sugar, cups), managing inventory levels, creating and adjusting their lemonade recipe (lemons and sugar per cup, affecting taste and cost), and setting the selling price per cup. The simulation includes dynamic weather conditions that influence customer demand, requiring students to adapt their strategies. Daily sales are simulated with an animated progress bar, providing real-time updates on cups sold and revenue. After each day, a detailed business report shows cups sold, daily revenue, cost of goods sold, and daily profit/loss, along with customer satisfaction feedback. The component is fully self-contained and requires no props, making it an ideal tool for exploring basic financial statements, price elasticity, demand sensitivity, and strategic decision-making in a fun and engaging way.
components.name: LemonadeStand for basic business operations and financial literacy simulation
StartupJourney for tech startup simulation and strategic decision-making
components.description: This component simulates the journey of a tech startup from idea to success, allowing students to make strategic decisions about funding, team, product, and growth over a 24-month period. It features a dashboard displaying key metrics like funding, monthly burn rate, user count, and revenue. Students progress through different startup stages (Idea, Prototype, Launch, Growth, Success) by making critical choices at each stage, such as initial funding strategy, hiring decisions, product development priorities, and marketing approaches. Each decision impacts the startup's financial health (funding, burn rate), user base, and revenue potential. The simulation includes win/loss conditions based on achieving revenue targets or running out of funding. It aims to teach students about the startup funding lifecycle, strategic decision-making under resource constraints, balancing growth and profitability, and risk management. The component is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: BarChart for financial data visualization and interpretation
components.description: A versatile and reusable bar chart component designed for visualizing financial data, supporting multiple datasets and customizable options. This component helps students learn to interpret and create bar charts for financial data visualization. Students interact by viewing bar charts showing financial metrics like revenue, expenses, and account balances. They can use interactive tooltips to see exact values and additional context, perform comparative analysis by viewing multiple data series side by side, and learn to read chart legends to identify different data categories. In interactive versions, students can also practice data input to see real-time chart updates. Key learning outcomes include understanding the visual representation of financial data, comparing multiple financial metrics, reading and interpreting chart legends and axes, identifying trends and patterns in business data, and developing professional data presentation skills. The component is built using Recharts and provides flexible options for height, width, and axis configuration, including support for horizontal bar charts.

An interactive chart component designed for visualizing break-even analysis, allowing students to understand the relationship between costs, volume, and profit. Students interact by adjusting key parameters: fixed costs, variable cost rate, and selling price using input controls. They observe in real-time how the revenue and total cost lines intersect at the break-even point on the chart. The component dynamically calculates and displays break-even units, break-even revenue, contribution margin, and contribution margin ratio. This allows students to test different cost structures and pricing strategies to understand their impact on profitability. Interactive tooltips provide exact values at various production levels. Key learning outcomes include understanding the relationship between fixed costs, variable costs, and revenue; calculating break-even points in units and dollars; analyzing contribution margin and its impact on profitability; visualizing cost-volume-profit relationships; and making informed business decisions based on break-even analysis. The component is built using Recharts and provides options for interactivity and display within a card.
components.name: BreakEvenChart for interactive break-even analysis visualization

components.description: A reusable doughnut chart component designed for visualizing proportional financial data, supporting customizable options and interactive segments. This component helps students learn to interpret and create doughnut charts for financial data visualization. Students interact by viewing doughnut charts that show the proportional breakdown of financial data, such as the composition of assets, liabilities, or expenses. They can analyze how parts relate to the whole through visual percentages and interactive segments. The component supports customizable inner and outer radii, and can optionally display a legend and percentages directly on the chart or in a summary. Key learning outcomes include understanding proportional representation of financial data, analyzing the composition of financial accounts and categories, reading and interpreting chart legends, understanding percentage breakdowns in business contexts, and developing professional data presentation skills for circular visualizations. It is built using Recharts and provides flexible options for height, width, and display within a card.
components.name: DoughnutChart for proportional financial data visualization

components.description: A comprehensive financial dashboard component designed to provide a high-level overview of a business's financial health. It displays key performance indicators (KPIs) such as total revenue, net profit, cash flow, and profit margin, with trend indicators. The dashboard includes multiple interactive charts built with Recharts: a line chart for monthly revenue vs. expenses trends, a pie chart for current account balances distribution, a bar chart for monthly cash flow and profit tracking, and a line chart for profit margin analysis. It also provides a summary of total revenue, expenses, and net profit over a period. The component is refreshable and exportable (simulated). This component is ideal for students to visualize and analyze integrated financial data, understand key financial metrics, and interpret trends in business performance. It is self-contained and uses sample data, but can be integrated with real data sources.
components.name: FinancialDashboard for comprehensive financial overview and KPI tracking
LineChart for visualizing financial trends over time
components.description: A reusable and highly customizable line chart component designed for visualizing financial data and trends over time. This component helps students learn to interpret and analyze time-series financial data. Students interact by viewing line charts that display metrics like revenue, expenses, stock prices, or cash flow over periods (e.g., months, quarters). They can identify trends, patterns, and volatility in the data. The component supports multiple datasets, interactive tooltips for detailed data points, and a customizable legend. It offers extensive configuration options including title, description, data, chart configuration (colors, labels), height, visibility of grid lines, X and Y axes, and legend, as well as custom value formatting for the Y-axis. Key learning outcomes include identifying financial trends, understanding growth and decline patterns, comparing performance over time, and developing skills in forecasting and data interpretation for business analysis.

components.name: PieChart for proportional financial data visualization and interpretation
components.description: A reusable pie chart component designed for visualizing proportional financial data, supporting customizable options and interactive segments. This component helps students learn to interpret and create pie charts for financial data visualization. Students interact by viewing pie charts that show the proportional breakdown of financial data, such as expense categories, revenue sources, or asset distributions. They can analyze how parts relate to the whole through visual percentages and interactive segments. The component supports customizable outer radius, and can optionally display a legend and percentages directly on the chart or in a summary. Key learning outcomes include understanding proportional representation of financial data, analyzing the composition of financial accounts and categories, reading and interpreting pie chart legends, understanding percentage breakdowns in business contexts, and developing professional data presentation skills for circular visualizations. It is built using Recharts and provides flexible options for height, width, and display within a card.

This component is an interactive drag-and-drop exercise designed to teach students how to categorize business transactions into the three main cash flow activities: Operating, Investing, and Financing. Students are presented with realistic business transaction descriptions and must drag each transaction card to the correct category zone. The component provides real-time visual feedback (green for correct, red for incorrect) and tracks the student's score and attempts. Transactions vary in difficulty, from straightforward examples to more nuanced cases. This exercise helps students understand the structure of a cash flow statement, distinguish between different types of business activities, and build a foundation for cash flow analysis. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.
components.name: BusinessTransactionCategorization for classifying cash flow activities
AccountCategorization for teaching the fundamental accounting equation and account classification
components.description: This interactive drag-and-drop exercise is designed to teach students the fundamental accounting equation (Assets = Liabilities + Equity) and how to categorize different business accounts into their proper classifications. Students interact by dragging 12 different business accounts (randomized order) from a bank to their correct category within a visual representation of the accounting equation (Assets on the left, Liabilities + Equity on the right, with additional sections for Revenue and Expenses). Each account includes student-friendly descriptions and real-world examples. A hint system can be toggled to reveal these examples, helping students connect abstract concepts to everyday experiences. Immediate feedback is provided when answers are checked: correct placements turn green, incorrect ones turn red, allowing students to move them and try again. The exercise tracks score and attempts, encouraging progressive learning through repeated practice. Key learning outcomes include understanding the accounting equation, identifying the 5 main account categories, classifying specific accounts, connecting terminology to real-world examples, and building a foundation for more advanced accounting topics. The component is fully self-contained and initializes with default accounts and randomization, requiring no props.

components.name: BreakEvenComponents for categorizing costs and calculating break-even points
components.description: This interactive drag-and-drop exercise is designed to teach students break-even analysis by categorizing business costs and understanding how fixed costs, variable costs, and revenue interact to determine the break-even point. Students are presented with 15 different business cost items and must drag them into either the 'Fixed Costs' or 'Variable Costs' categories. They can also adjust the selling price per unit to observe its impact. As costs are categorized, the component dynamically calculates and displays total fixed costs, variable cost per unit, contribution margin, break-even units, and break-even dollars. The exercise provides real-time validation of cost categorizations and updates calculations as items are placed. It includes educational explanations for each cost type and a 'How to Play' guide detailing objectives, instructions, cost categories, formulas, and pro tips. This component helps students visualize cost behavior patterns, apply break-even analysis to business decisions, and understand the minimum sales needed to cover all costs and start generating profit. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: CashFlowTimeline for visualizing and managing cash flow timing
components.description: This interactive drag-and-drop exercise is designed to teach students to visualize and arrange cash flows on a timeline, fostering an understanding of cash management timing, working capital needs, and liquidity planning. Students interact by dragging cash inflow (green) and outflow (red) items from a source area onto a 12-week horizontal timeline. As items are placed, the component provides real-time analysis, calculating and displaying the running cash balance week by week, highlighting critical weeks where cash runs low, and indicating net cash flow for each period. The exercise includes a 'How to Play' guide detailing objectives, instructions, cash flow categories (inflows vs. outflows), business context (managing a manufacturing company), and success tips for identifying timing clues and critical payments. Students can check their answers for validation and receive feedback on correct/incorrect placements, or choose to reveal the correct timeline. This component helps students connect operational activities to cash management and plan for potential cash shortages or surpluses. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: FinancialStatementMatching for categorizing financial line items
components.description: This interactive drag-and-drop exercise is designed to teach students to identify and categorize financial statement line items, understanding which items belong to the Income Statement, Balance Sheet, and Cash Flow Statement. Students interact by dragging various financial line items (e.g., 'Sales Revenue', 'Cash', 'Accounts Payable') from a source area to the appropriate financial statement drop zone. The component provides real-time visual feedback (green for correct, red for incorrect) and tracks the student's score and attempts. It includes a comprehensive 'How to Play' guide with objective explanations, win conditions, detailed definitions of each financial statement, key characteristics, examples of items for each statement type, and pro tips for remembering categorization rules. This exercise builds foundational knowledge for financial statement analysis, helps distinguish between operating, investing, and financing activities, and develops accounting vocabulary and categorization skills. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: TrialBalanceSorting for organizing accounts into a trial balance
components.description: This interactive drag-and-drop exercise is designed to teach students how to organize accounts into a trial balance format, understanding which accounts have normal debit or credit balances and verifying that total debits equal total credits. Students interact by viewing a shuffled list of accounts with their dollar amounts and dragging each account to either the "Debit Balances" or "Credit Balances" column based on its normal balance. As accounts are placed, the component provides real-time running totals for both debit and credit sides, along with a balance status indicator showing if the trial balance is balanced. Students learn which accounts typically have DEBIT balances (Assets, Expenses) and CREDIT balances (Liabilities, Equity, Revenues). The exercise reinforces the fundamental accounting principle that total debits must equal total credits. It provides immediate feedback on placements and allows students to reset and retry. Key learning outcomes include understanding normal account balances, recognizing account types, experiencing the trial balance as a verification tool, and developing familiarity with account classification systems. The component is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: ComprehensionCheck for multiple-choice quizzes and assessments
components.description: A versatile multiple-choice comprehension check component designed for educational assessments. It presents a series of questions with randomized answer options. Students interact by selecting an answer for each question. Upon submission, the component provides immediate feedback, indicating correct and incorrect answers with visual cues (green for correct, red for incorrect). It can optionally display detailed explanations for each answer, helping students understand the reasoning behind the correct choice. The component tracks the student's score and allows for retries, encouraging learning and mastery. It is highly configurable, allowing control over the display of explanations and retry functionality. This component is ideal for formative assessments, quick checks for understanding, and reinforcing learning objectives.

components.name: DragAndDrop for interactive matching exercises
components.description: A versatile drag-and-drop matching exercise component designed for educational purposes, allowing users to match items from a left column to corresponding drop zones in a right column. This component facilitates interactive learning for various subjects, such as vocabulary terms and definitions, accounting entries and explanations, or formulas and their meanings. Students interact by dragging items, receiving real-time visual feedback (green for correct, red for incorrect), and can move items between drop zones until correct. An optional hint system provides additional context. The component tracks progress with a real-time score and attempt counter, encouraging self-paced learning and mastery. It includes built-in instructions explaining the objective, step-by-step interaction, and success tips. Key learning outcomes include active engagement with content, immediate reinforcement of correct associations, visual and spatial memory reinforcement, and confidence building through gamified success metrics. It is highly configurable via props for items, titles, hints, and shuffling.

components.name: FillInTheBlank for interactive gap-fill exercises
components.description: An interactive fill-in-the-blank exercise component designed for educational purposes, allowing students to complete sentences with missing words or phrases. It presents sentences with highlighted blank spaces where students type their answers. The component supports an optional word bank (which can be randomized) and a hint system to provide additional context. Real-time visual feedback is provided as students type (green for correct, red for incorrect), and case-insensitive matching is supported. The exercise tracks the student's score and attempts, encouraging self-paced learning and mastery. It includes built-in instructions explaining the objective, step-by-step interaction, and success tips. This component is versatile and can be used for vocabulary building, formula completion, sentence construction, and other text completion exercises across various subjects. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

This component is an interactive exercise designed to teach students how to create proper journal entries for business transactions, reinforcing the double-entry bookkeeping principle and account classifications. Students interact by reading a business transaction scenario, then dragging account names from an "Available Accounts" bank into a journal entry table. They then input monetary amounts into either the Debit or Credit columns. The component provides real-time feedback on the balance of debits and credits, indicating if the entry is balanced. Upon submission, it validates the entry against the correct accounts, proper debit/credit placement, and equal totals, providing specific feedback on any errors. The exercise includes a "How to Play" guide detailing objectives, step-by-step instructions, debit/credit rules for different account types, account categories, and success tips. Students can reset the entry or move to the next scenario upon successful completion. Key learning outcomes include understanding double-entry bookkeeping fundamentals, proper account classification, debit and credit rules, and transaction analysis skills. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.
components.name: JournalEntryBuilding for interactive journal entry creation and validation

components.description: A comprehensive and highly detailed balance sheet component designed to display a company's financial position at a specific point in time. It presents a granular breakdown of assets (current and non-current, including cash, receivables, inventory, property, plant & equipment, intangibles, and investments), liabilities (current and long-term, including payables, short-term debt, long-term debt, and other liabilities), and equity (paid-in capital, retained earnings, and other equity). The component automatically calculates and displays key financial ratios such as Current Ratio, Quick Ratio, Debt-to-Equity Ratio, Debt-to-Assets Ratio, Working Capital, and Equity Ratio. It provides financial health indicators based on these ratios and includes an interactive toggle to show or hide detailed sub-account breakdowns. A crucial feature is its validation of the fundamental accounting equation (Assets = Liabilities + Equity), visually indicating if the balance sheet is in balance or highlighting any discrepancies. This component is ideal for students to deeply analyze a company's financial structure, liquidity, solvency, and leverage, and to understand the interrelationships between different financial accounts. It uses sample data but is designed to be integrated with real financial data.
components.name: BalanceSheetDetailed for comprehensive financial position analysis

components.description: A simplified balance sheet component designed to provide a clear and concise overview of a company's financial position at a specific point in time. It presents key categories of assets (current and fixed), liabilities (current and long-term), and equity. The component automatically calculates and displays essential financial ratios such as Current Ratio, Debt-to-Equity Ratio, and Working Capital, along with qualitative interpretations of these ratios (e.g., 'Strong liquidity', 'Conservative leverage'). It also validates the fundamental accounting equation (Assets = Liabilities + Equity), visually indicating if the statement is balanced. This component is ideal for students to grasp the basic structure of a balance sheet, understand the accounting equation, and interpret fundamental financial health indicators without being overwhelmed by granular details. It uses sample data but is designed to be integrated with real financial data.
components.name: BalanceSheetSimple for simplified financial position overview
CashFlowStatementDetailed for comprehensive cash flow analysis
components.description: A comprehensive and highly detailed cash flow statement component designed to display a company's cash inflows and outflows over a specific period, categorized into operating, investing, and financing activities. It presents a granular breakdown of each activity, including adjustments for non-cash items and changes in working capital for operating activities, capital expenditures and asset sales for investing activities, and equity and debt transactions for financing activities. The component calculates the net change in cash and reconciles it with beginning and ending cash balances. It also includes supplemental disclosures for interest and taxes paid, and non-cash transactions. An interactive toggle allows users to show or hide detailed breakdowns within each section. This component is ideal for students to deeply analyze a company's cash generation and usage, understand the different sources and uses of cash, and interpret the overall liquidity and solvency of a business. It uses sample data but is designed to be integrated with real financial data.

A simplified cash flow statement component designed to provide a clear and concise overview of a company's cash inflows and outflows over a specific period. It categorizes cash flows into three main activities: operating (cash from day-to-day business), investing (cash from buying/selling long-term assets), and financing (cash from dealings with owners and creditors). The component calculates the net change in cash and reconciles it with beginning and ending cash balances. It also includes an optional section explaining the purpose of each cash flow activity. This component is ideal for students to grasp the basic structure of a cash flow statement, understand the different sources and uses of cash, and interpret the overall liquidity of a business without being overwhelmed by granular details. It uses sample data but is designed to be integrated with real financial data.
components.name: CashFlowStatementSimple for simplified cash flow overview

components.description: A comprehensive and highly detailed income statement component designed to display a company's financial performance over a specific period. It presents a granular breakdown of revenues (product sales, service sales, other revenues), cost of goods sold (including beginning/ending inventory, purchases, labor, overhead), gross profit, operating expenses (selling and administrative, with sub-categories like advertising, salaries, depreciation), operating income, non-operating items (interest income/expense, gains/losses), income before taxes, income taxes, and net income. The component automatically calculates and displays key profitability ratios such as Gross Margin, Operating Margin, Net Margin, and Expense Ratio. An interactive toggle allows users to show or hide detailed breakdowns within each section. This component is ideal for students to deeply analyze a company's revenue generation, cost structure, and profitability at various levels, and to understand the factors influencing net income. It uses sample data but is designed to be integrated with real financial data.
components.name: IncomeStatementDetailed for comprehensive financial performance analysis

components.description: A simplified income statement component designed to provide a clear and concise overview of a company's financial performance over a specific period. It presents key revenue and expense figures, along with profitability metrics. The component automatically calculates and displays essential profitability ratios such as Gross Margin, Operating Margin, and Net Margin. It also includes an optional section explaining the key calculations involved in an income statement. This component is ideal for students to grasp the basic structure of an income statement and understand fundamental profitability indicators without being overwhelmed by granular details. It uses sample data but is designed to be integrated with real financial data.
components.name: IncomeStatementSimple for simplified financial performance overview
SpreadsheetTemplates for providing pre-built Excel-like worksheets
components.description: This component provides a collection of predefined, interactive spreadsheet templates for various business and accounting scenarios, designed to be used within an Excel-like environment. It includes templates for: T-Accounts (Unit 1): Basic T-Account structure for tracking debits and credits, with automatic summation. Trial Balance (Unit 2): Worksheet with automatic balance checking to verify debits equal credits. Income Statement (Unit 3): Basic income statement with revenue, expenses, and net income calculation. Statistical Analysis (Unit 4): Template for analyzing sales data with statistical functions like AVERAGE, MAX, MIN, and SUM. Payroll (Unit 5): Basic payroll calculation with gross pay, tax, and net pay deductions. Break-Even Analysis (Unit 6): Cost-Volume-Profit analysis with break-even point calculation and scenario analysis. Each template is structured with read-only labels and editable cells, and includes built-in formulas (e.g., `=SUM`, `=IF`, `=B5-B4`) to demonstrate calculations. This component allows students to practice data entry, observe real-time calculations, and understand the structure of various financial and analytical documents in a familiar spreadsheet format.

A comprehensive teacher-facing component designed to display a detailed unit lesson plan. It is structured according to the 'Understanding by Design' framework, covering three stages: 'Identify Desired Results' (Essential Question, Enduring Understandings, Knowledge, and Skills), 'Determine Acceptable Evidence' (Performance Task, Milestone Assessments, and Rubric), and 'Plan Learning Experiences and Instruction' (Learning Sequence Overview and Detailed Daily Plans with activities, videos, and interactive elements). The component also includes sections for Assessment Strategies, Differentiation Support, Required Resources & Materials, and Reflection & Continuous Improvement questions. It uses the `UnitLessonPlan` type from `@/types/lesson-plan` to structure the data. This component provides teachers with a complete and organized view of the unit's pedagogical approach, learning objectives, assessment methods, and daily instructional activities.
components.name: UnitLessonPlanComponent for displaying detailed unit lesson plans for teachers

components.description: A comprehensive teacher-facing component designed to display a high-level overview of an educational unit. It presents essential information such as the unit number, title, and description, along with meta-data like duration, grade level, and course. Key sections include the unit's Essential Question, Learning Targets (what students will be able to do), specific Excel Skills and Business Skills to be developed, and a summary of Key Assessments. Crucially, it highlights the unit's connection to the overall Capstone Project, demonstrating how the unit builds towards larger learning goals. This component provides teachers with a concise yet thorough summary of the unit's pedagogical framework and learning objectives, facilitating planning and understanding of the curriculum progression. It expects a `unitOverview` prop of type `UnitOverviewType` from `@/types/lesson-plan`.
components.name: UnitOverviewComponent for displaying a high-level unit overview for teachers
AssessmentOverview for displaying unit assessment details and rubrics
components.description: A component designed to display a comprehensive overview of unit assessments, providing students with clear expectations for their performance. It prominently features the `Final Performance Task`, detailing its title, description, specific requirements, and authentic context. Additionally, it outlines `Key Milestones`, which are formative assessments with titles, descriptions, and criteria, helping students track their progress throughout the unit. The component also includes an `Assessment Rubric` preview, breaking down evaluation criteria by name, weight, and proficiency levels (Exemplary, Proficient, Developing). This detailed presentation helps students understand how their work will be evaluated, what skills they need to demonstrate, and how to achieve success in both summative and formative assessments. It expects an `assessment` prop containing the structured data for the performance task, milestones, and rubric.

A component designed to prominently display a unit's driving question, providing essential context and an optional real-world scenario to engage students and frame their learning. It serves as the central inquiry that guides the unit's exploration, encouraging students to think critically and connect concepts to practical applications. The component visually highlights the question and its supporting details, making it a focal point for student attention. It expects a `drivingQuestion` prop which includes the `question` itself, its `context`, and an optional `scenario`.
components.name: DrivingQuestion for engaging students with a unit's core inquiry
LearningSequence for displaying a unit's weekly and daily learning plan
components.description: A component designed to display a unit's learning sequence, broken down by weeks and days, providing a structured overview of the curriculum. It presents each week with a title and description, and then details each day within that week, including its focus, activities, and resources. Key features include: visual badges for week and day numbers; clear headings for daily focus areas; bulleted lists for activities; and badges for associated resources. It also highlights `milestones` within the daily sequence, indicating important checkpoints for student progress. This component helps students and teachers understand the flow of learning, manage their time effectively, and track the progression of topics and skills throughout the unit. It expects a `learningSequence` prop containing an array of `Week` objects.

components.name: Prerequisites for displaying unit requirements and resources
components.description: A component designed to display prerequisites and required resources for a unit, ensuring students are prepared before starting new content. It outlines necessary prior knowledge, technology requirements (e.g., software, internet access), and provides links to downloadable or external resources (e.g., templates, articles). The component also includes an optional section for differentiation strategies, offering tailored support for struggling students, advanced students, and English Language Learners (ELLs). This helps teachers and students identify and address any gaps in preparation, ensuring a smoother learning experience. It expects a `prerequisites` prop containing `knowledge`, `technology`, and `resources`, and an optional `differentiation` prop.

components.name: StudentChoices for enabling student voice and choice in unit activities
components.description: A component designed to display options for student voice and choice within a unit, empowering students to take ownership of their learning. It can present choices across various aspects of a project-based learning unit, such as: `Venture Selection` (allowing students to choose from provided startup ideas or propose their own); `Team Roles` (enabling students to select roles based on their strengths and interests); and `Presentation Formats` (offering flexibility in how students present their work, e.g., pitch deck, video, written report). The component dynamically renders sections based on the available choices, providing clear labels and descriptions for each option. This promotes student engagement, caters to diverse learning styles, and encourages personalized learning paths. It expects a `studentChoices` prop which can optionally contain arrays for `ventures`, `roles`, and `presentationFormats`.

components.name: UnitHeader for displaying unit overview and key metadata
components.description: A header component designed to provide a concise and visually appealing overview of an educational unit. It prominently displays the unit number, title, and a brief description, serving as an immediate introduction to the unit's content. Key metadata such as the estimated duration of the unit and its difficulty level (Beginner, Intermediate, Advanced) are also presented, with the difficulty level indicated by a color-coded badge and an emoji. This component helps students quickly grasp the scope and challenge of the unit, while also providing teachers with essential planning information. It is designed to be used at the top of unit-specific pages.

components.name: UnitIntroduction for introducing a unit's content and objectives
components.description: A component designed to display the introduction to an educational unit, providing students with a comprehensive overview of what they will learn and achieve. It features a prominent display of the unit's driving question, an optional introductory video, and details about an engaging 'Entry Event' with activities and resources to kickstart the unit. The component also outlines the 'Project Challenge', including the scenario, team structure, final deliverable, and timeline, aligning with project-based learning methodologies. Furthermore, it clearly articulates the learning objectives, broken down into content knowledge, Excel skills, and deliverables. This component serves as a crucial onboarding tool, setting expectations and motivating students for the upcoming unit. It expects a `UnitIntroductionData` prop which includes `unitNumber`, `unitTitle`, `drivingQuestion`, `introVideo`, `entryEvent`, `projectOverview`, `learningObjectives`, and `nextSectionHref`.

components.name: UnitOverview for displaying a unit's learning objectives and deliverables
components.description: A component designed to display a high-level overview of a unit's learning objectives, broken down into three key areas: `Learning Objectives` (content knowledge students will acquire), `Tools & Skills` (practical skills, often Excel-based, students will develop), and `Final Deliverables` (the tangible outputs students will produce). This component provides a concise summary of the unit's educational goals, helping students understand what they are expected to learn and achieve. It is typically used on a unit's main overview page to set expectations and provide a roadmap for learning. It expects an `objectives` prop containing arrays for `content`, `skills`, and `deliverables`.

A comprehensive template component designed to display the entire content of an educational unit. It acts as a wrapper that composes several other unit-related components, including `UnitHeader` (for unit overview and metadata), `UnitOverview` (for learning objectives and deliverables), `DrivingQuestion` (for the unit's core inquiry), `AssessmentOverview` (for assessment details and rubrics), `LearningSequence` (for weekly and daily learning plans), `StudentChoices` (for student voice and choice options), and `Prerequisites` (for unit requirements and resources). This component takes a `unitData` prop, which is an object containing all the necessary information for a unit, and intelligently passes the relevant parts to its child components. It provides a structured and complete view of an educational unit, facilitating a holistic understanding for both students and teachers.
components.name: UnitTemplate for displaying a comprehensive educational unit
ReflectionJournal for student self-reflection on learning experiences
components.description: A component for student self-reflection on learning experiences, supporting the CAP (Courage, Adaptability, Persistence) framework used throughout the Grade 12 Business Operations curriculum. Students reflect on their learning journey and develop metacognitive awareness. It presents a series of reflection prompts categorized by Courage, Adaptability, and Persistence. Students interact by typing their responses into multi-line text areas. The component tracks the completion status of each prompt and provides a progress indicator. Responses can be saved (via an optional `onSave` callback). Each prompt includes a category badge and an emoji icon for visual distinction. This component encourages metacognition and personal growth by guiding students through structured reflection on their challenges, adjustments, and perseverance during the unit.

components.name: RatioMatching for matching financial ratios to their formulas
components.description: This interactive drag-and-drop exercise is designed to teach students to identify and match key financial ratios to their corresponding formulas, building a foundation for financial statement analysis. Students interact by dragging 8 different financial ratios (randomized order) from a bank to their correct formula in the matching zones. The exercise covers four key categories: Liquidity, Profitability, Efficiency, and Leverage ratios. Each ratio includes its business meaning and investor perspective. A hint system can be toggled to reveal what each ratio measures, industry benchmarks, and why it matters to investors. Immediate feedback is provided when answers are checked (green for correct, red for incorrect), and students can reposition incorrect matches. The component tracks score and attempts, encouraging progressive learning. Key learning outcomes include identifying essential financial ratios, connecting formulas to financial statement accounts, understanding what each ratio measures, and recognizing the four main categories of financial analysis ratios. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: BudgetCategorySort for organizing café operating expenses into budget categories
components.description: An interactive drag-and-drop exercise designed to teach students to organize café operating expenses into budget categories. Students interact by dragging 15 different café expenses from a randomized bank to their correct budget category (COGS, Labor, Overhead, Marketing, Administrative). The component provides real-time feedback on placements, including profit impact indicators, and tracks the student's score and attempts. A hint system can be toggled to reveal detailed explanations of each budget category and its impact on profit margins. This exercise connects to Unit 4's POS data analysis by showing how different expense categories affect profitability and waste reduction goals, building a foundation for data-driven operations optimization. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: RatioMatching for matching financial ratios to their formulas
components.description: This interactive drag-and-drop exercise is designed to teach students to identify and match key financial ratios to their corresponding formulas, building a foundation for financial statement analysis. Students interact by dragging 8 different financial ratios (randomized order) from a bank to their correct formula in the matching zones. The exercise covers four key categories: Liquidity, Profitability, Efficiency, and Leverage ratios. Each ratio includes its business meaning and investor perspective. A hint system can be toggled to reveal what each ratio measures, industry benchmarks, and why it matters to investors. Immediate feedback is provided when answers are checked (green for correct, red for incorrect), and students can reposition incorrect matches. The component tracks score and attempts, encouraging progressive learning. Key learning outcomes include identifying essential financial ratios, connecting formulas to financial statement accounts, understanding what each ratio measures, and recognizing the four main categories of financial analysis ratios. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: BudgetCategorySort for organizing café operating expenses into budget categories
components.description: An interactive drag-and-drop exercise designed to teach students to organize café operating expenses into budget categories. Students interact by dragging 15 different café expenses from a randomized bank to their correct budget category (COGS, Labor, Overhead, Marketing, Administrative). The component provides real-time feedback on placements, including profit impact indicators, and tracks the student's score and attempts. A hint system can be toggled to reveal detailed explanations of each budget category and its impact on profit margins. This exercise connects to Unit 4's POS data analysis by showing how different expense categories affect profitability and waste reduction goals, building a foundation for data-driven operations optimization. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: PercentageCalculationSorting for categorizing business scenarios by percentage calculation type
components.description: This interactive drag-and-drop exercise is designed to teach students to categorize different percentage calculations used in business operations analysis, supporting Unit 4's data-driven café optimization theme. Students interact by dragging 18 different café business scenarios to their correct calculation type category: Percentage Change, Percentage of Total, Percentage Increase/Decrease, or Weighted Average. Each scenario includes real-world café-specific business problems. The component provides real-time feedback on placements, including calculation formulas, and tracks the student's score and attempts. A hint system can be toggled to reveal calculation formulas and business applications for each percentage type. This exercise reinforces mathematical foundations needed for POS data analysis, prepares students for statistical analysis and interpretation, connects percentage calculations to real business decision-making, and supports Excel Analysis ToolPak work. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: InterestCalculationBuilder for financial interest and cash flow management
components.description: An interactive calculator designed to teach students different types of interest calculations relevant to business cash flow management, specifically focusing on scenarios encountered in Unit 5's PayDay Simulator. Students can select from various business scenarios (e.g., payroll bridge loans, equipment financing, invoice factoring) and explore four key calculation types: simple interest, compound interest, annuity payments, and present value. The component provides an interactive formula builder, shows actual Excel formulas, and offers business interpretations and advice for each result. It emphasizes connecting mathematical concepts to real-world payroll timing challenges and financial decision-making. The component is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: BreakEvenAnalysisCalculator for advanced CVP modeling and sensitivity analysis
components.description: An advanced break-even analysis calculator designed to teach students comprehensive cost-volume-profit (CVP) modeling, including Goal Seek, one- and two-variable data tables, and sensitivity analysis. Students interact by inputting fixed costs, variable costs per unit, and selling price to establish baseline break-even calculations. They can then use the 'Goal Seek' feature to reverse-engineer required changes (sales volume, price, or cost reductions) needed to achieve a target profit. The 'Data Tables' allow for extensive what-if scenario analysis by varying one or two inputs simultaneously, generating profit sensitivity matrices. The component also calculates and interprets the margin of safety (in units, dollars, and ratio) and operating leverage to assess business risk. It provides an executive summary with strategic recommendations based on the analysis and offers functionality to export the analysis to Excel for professional presentations. This component is ideal for Unit 6 PriceLab Challenge, where students analyze competitor pricing data and build compelling pricing recommendations. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: InventoryFlowDiagram for visualizing FIFO/LIFO inventory cost flow
components.description: This interactive drag-and-drop exercise is designed to teach students FIFO (First-In, First-Out) and LIFO (Last-In, First-Out) inventory cost flow visualization, supporting Unit 7's Asset & Inventory Tracker theme. Students interact by arranging randomized inventory lots (each with purchase date, quantity, and unit cost) in the correct order for either FIFO or LIFO cost flow assumptions. The component provides real-time calculation of Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) and ending inventory based on their arrangement and specified sales quantity. It includes realistic business scenarios (e.g., tech retailer, coffee café, auto parts dealer) to provide context. Students can switch between FIFO and LIFO modes to compare how the same transactions result in different COGS and ending inventory values, and analyze the financial impact. The exercise provides immediate feedback on the correctness of their arrangement and tracks score and attempts. It also allows for dynamic sales transaction quantity input and toggling. This component helps students understand inventory valuation principles, their impact on financial reporting, and their connection to business strategy and tax planning. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: DepreciationMethodBuilder for comparing and calculating asset depreciation
components.description: A comprehensive and interactive component designed to teach students four standard depreciation methods: Straight-line, Double Declining Balance, Sum-of-Years-Digits, and Units of Production. Students interact by selecting from four realistic asset scenarios (e.g., Commercial Oven, Delivery Truck, POS System, Manufacturing Equipment), each with pre-configured costs, salvage values, and useful lives. They can input custom asset values and see instant year-by-year depreciation schedules for each method. The component highlights the tax strategy implications of accelerated versus straight-line depreciation and provides business context for method selection. It also generates Excel formulas (SLN, DDB, SYD) for real-world business modeling. This component is ideal for Unit 7 Asset & Inventory Tracker, where students learn to analyze asset management decisions, their impact on cash flow and financial statements, and develop tax planning strategies. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: DepreciationMethodBuilder for comparing and calculating asset depreciation
components.description: A comprehensive and interactive component designed to teach students four standard depreciation methods: Straight-line, Double Declining Balance, Sum-of-Years-Digits, and Units of Production. Students interact by selecting from four realistic asset scenarios (e.g., Commercial Oven, Delivery Truck, POS System, Manufacturing Equipment), each with pre-configured costs, salvage values, and useful lives. They can input custom asset values and see instant year-by-year depreciation schedules for each method. The component highlights the tax strategy implications of accelerated versus straight-line depreciation and provides business context for method selection. It also generates Excel formulas (SLN, DDB, SYD) for real-world business modeling. This component is ideal for Unit 7 Asset & Inventory Tracker, where students learn to analyze asset management decisions, their impact on cash flow and financial statements, and develop tax planning strategies. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: TAccountsVisualization for demonstrating the accounting equation with multiple T-accounts
components.description: A visual and interactive component designed to demonstrate the fundamental accounting equation (Assets = Liabilities + Equity) through multiple T-accounts. Students interact by observing how transactions affect individual T-accounts and how these changes collectively impact the overall accounting equation. Key features include: a dynamic display of the accounting equation with real-time balance verification (showing if Assets equal Liabilities + Equity); color-coded T-accounts based on account type (asset, liability, equity); and the ability to select individual T-accounts to highlight their details. This component is ideal for Unit 1 Smart Ledger Launch, helping students visualize the double-entry bookkeeping system, understand the flow of transactions, and grasp the core concept of financial balance. It uses sample data but can be populated with custom account data.

components.name: TransactionJournal for managing startup transactions and building a self-auditing ledger system
components.description: This component provides an interactive transaction journal for managing startup transactions and building a self-auditing ledger system. It allows students to record, track, and validate business transactions for their chosen client focus (e.g., Tech Startup, E-commerce Business). Key features include: the ability to add new transactions with date, description, and journal entry lines; real-time balance validation to ensure debits equal credits; and analytics to track total transactions, balanced/unbalanced entries, and accuracy rate. Students can select from common accounts and specify account types (asset, liability, equity, revenue, expense). The component also includes a "How to Use" guide detailing step-by-step instructions, key learning outcomes (double-entry bookkeeping, account classification, transaction analysis), and quick reference for account types and their debit/credit rules. This tool supports Unit 1: Smart Ledger Launch, helping students practice financial record-keeping and build confidence in maintaining "clean books" for investor presentations. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: PeerCritiqueForm for structured peer feedback and evaluation
components.description: A structured peer feedback form designed for students to provide constructive criticism on project presentations, Excel models, and business analysis work. This component facilitates the development of critical evaluation skills and professional business communication within a collaborative learning environment. Students interact by rating five key evaluation categories (Strengths, Areas for Improvement, Excel Technical Skills, Business Insight, and Presentation Delivery) using a 1-5 star system, and providing detailed written comments for each. The form guides students with specific prompts and placeholders to ensure actionable feedback. It tracks completion status for both ratings and comments, and calculates an overall progress and average rating. The component also includes an expandable 'Feedback Guidelines' section that explains feedback principles, provides a guide for each category, and offers examples of good vs. bad feedback. It is designed to mirror professional peer review processes, preparing students for workplace collaboration. The form can optionally capture the reviewer's name and triggers an `onSubmit` callback with the complete feedback data. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: ErrorCheckingSystem for building conditional formatting rules and data validation
components.description: An interactive component that teaches students to build conditional formatting rules for business data validation. Students learn to create automated error checking systems using Excel conditional formatting and formulas. It teaches four key validation types: Range Validation (values outside acceptable ranges), Logic Validation (data violating business rules), Format Validation (incorrect data formats), and Completeness Validation (missing data). Each scenario includes real-world business contexts (Payroll, Inventory, Financial) and shows the actual Excel conditional formatting formulas (e.g., IF, AND, OR, ISNUMBER, ISBLANK). The interactive rule builder allows students to identify conditions, construct formulas, apply color coding, and test rules against sample data to verify accuracy. This component uses SafeFormulaEvaluator for safe formula testing and is essential for Unit 2's Month-End Wizard, where automated error checking reduces closing time from days to hours. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: PitchPresentationBuilder for interactive investor pitch preparation
components.description: An interactive component designed to help students prepare a professional 4-minute investor pitch presentation for their capstone business model. Students interact by choosing a business model and then building their pitch across 6 essential sections: Problem, Solution, Market, Business Model, Financials, and Ask. The component provides an interactive content builder with real-time timer, speaking notes, and pacing indicators for practice. It also includes AI-powered content suggestions and visual slide previews. Key learning outcomes include professional presentation and storytelling skills, understanding investor mindset, financial projections, market analysis, and persuasive communication. The component tracks content completeness and practice time, and allows for exporting the pitch deck. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: FeedbackCollector for expert stakeholder feedback on student projects
components.description: This component is a structured feedback form designed for industry experts (e.g., investors, CPAs, entrepreneurs, consultants, bankers) to provide professional feedback on student business models, financial projections, and presentations. It facilitates authentic audience engagement and real-world validation of academic work within the Project-Based Learning (PBL) methodology. Experts interact by rating six key evaluation categories (Financial Accuracy, Business Viability, Presentation Quality, Industry Knowledge, Innovation Potential, Implementation Readiness) using a professional 5-level rating system (Needs Work, Developing, Proficient, Advanced, Expert). They also provide detailed written comments for each category, guided by stakeholder-specific prompts. The form includes sections for overall strategic recommendations, mentorship offers, and career guidance, and can track interest in follow-up opportunities. It captures the expert's name and company. This component prepares students for workplace feedback and mentorship relationships, aligning with industry practices. It is fully self-contained and requires no props.

components.name: UnitProjectFramework for defining the structure of authentic capstone projects
components.description: The `UnitProjectFramework` is a TypeScript interface that defines a standardized structure for authentic capstone projects across all 8 educational units. It outlines the core components of a project-based learning experience, including: a `performanceTask` (detailing the authentic business scenario, audience, context, deliverables, requirements, and duration); `milestones` (progressive checkpoints with criteria and deliverables); a `rubric` (standardized criteria for assessment); `studentChoices` (options for scenarios, roles, and presentation formats to empower student voice); and `resources` (templates, datasets, guides, and external links for self-contained classroom implementation). This framework ensures consistency in project design, facilitates professional presentation opportunities, and supports the integration of real-world business practices into the curriculum. It is used by developers and curriculum designers to structure unit data, ensuring all necessary elements for a comprehensive project are included.

components.name: UnitProjectFrameworks for managing a collection of standardized unit capstone projects
components.description: This component represents a complete collection of 8 unit project frameworks, implementing standardized summative assessments across the curriculum. Each framework defines an authentic performance task (e.g., investor pitches, Innovation Fair demos, board presentations), a progressive 3-milestone structure, weighted rubrics, and self-contained classroom resources. It supports the Grade 12 project-based learning methodology with real professional audience engagement. This data structure is crucial for curriculum designers and developers to ensure consistency and quality in the design and implementation of capstone projects for each unit.

components.name: AssessmentUtilities for creating, validating, and managing summative assessments
components.description: A collection of comprehensive utility functions designed for creating, validating, and managing summative assessments based on standardized unit project frameworks. These utilities ensure consistency across all units while maintaining flexibility for unit-specific requirements. Key functionalities include: `validateUnitProjectFramework` for validating a framework against standard requirements (checking for errors and warnings in structure, milestones, and rubrics); `generateStandardMilestones` for creating standard milestone structures; `generateStandardRubric` for generating rubrics with customizable focus areas; `suggestAuthenticAudience` for recommending appropriate audiences based on unit focus; `analyzeAssessmentCoverage` for analyzing assessment distribution across units (audience, formats, skills, standards); `getAssessmentTimeline` for retrieving unit-specific assessment timelines; `validateClassroomResources` for validating resource availability for classroom-only implementation; and `generateResourceChecklist` for creating a checklist of required resources. These utilities are primarily used by curriculum developers and teachers to design, implement, and evaluate project-based learning assessments effectively.

components.name: TeacherLessonPlan for displaying detailed lesson plans for teachers
components.description: This component provides a comprehensive teacher-facing lesson plan, structured with a 6-phase PBL (Project-Based Learning) model (Hook, Introduction, Guided Practice, Independent Practice, Assessment, Closing). It includes a lesson selector dropdown for direct navigation to any lesson within the unit, along with quick previous/next buttons for adjacent lessons. For each lesson, it displays learning objectives, key concepts, pedagogical approaches, and a rationale. Each phase within a lesson details its description, developer notes, teaching tips, timing guidance, and required materials. This component is designed for the Grade 12 Math for Business Operations curriculum, offering enhanced teacher navigation and detailed pedagogical support.

components.name: BusinessTerms Data for providing bilingual business terminology
components.description: A comprehensive bilingual business terminology database for Mandarin-speaking students. This data component provides English terms with simplified Chinese translations, pinyin pronunciations, definitions at an 8th-grade reading level, and practical examples. It also includes cultural context notes and relevant Excel function references where applicable. The terms are organized and filterable by unit, category (e.g., accounting, excel, finance, statistics, cost-analysis, assets, inventory, financial-modeling), and difficulty level (basic, intermediate, advanced). This data is consumed by components like `BilingualVocabularyGlossary` to support language learners and reinforce key business concepts.

components.name: UnitSidebar for unit navigation and progress tracking
components.description: A sticky sidebar component designed for unit-specific navigation and progress tracking within the educational application. It prominently displays the current unit's number, title, and overall completion percentage. The sidebar lists all lessons within the unit, showing each lesson's sequence, title, estimated duration, and individual progress percentage. The current lesson is visually highlighted, and completed lessons are marked with a check icon. Students can click on any lesson to navigate directly to it. The component also provides a quick action button to access the unit's main overview page. It integrates with the `LessonProgressContext` to calculate and display real-time progress for both individual lessons and the entire unit, enhancing the student's awareness of their learning journey. Built using `Card`, `Separator`, `Button`, `Badge`, and `Progress` UI components, and `next/link` for efficient navigation.
